title: Opening

organizer: Joao Schwarz da Silva, Converged Networks and Services, European Commission

segmentation: OK, good morning everyone.
I never expected to have so many people interested in such a subject, but it's it's quite pleasant to see that so many people in Europe are interested in this business.
First of all, I mean David.
Many thanks for hosting us here and this magnificent facilities for me.
It's not the first time when I come to Brussels.
I came first time 30 years ago.
I agree with you, it seldom rains.
The cars project I would like to say also Many thanks because this is one of those.
The key initiatives we have which would hopefully allow us to better coordinate our efforts.
'cause at the end of the day it's all about critical mass of resources and how we go about doing something that makes sense in European context.
Now the problem we're all confronted with the problem, which sometimes is described as a long wave problem in the sense that we cannot really anticipate what may happen.
We don't have a reference point to judge from, and we're a bit a bit in the dark in terms of understanding user requirements and understanding how we define and describe content.
Now, this is what I'd like to share with you, perhaps not as a statement, but a few thoughts.
To start with, I mean this is the classical iceberg picture.
I mean, most of us can describe knowledge in explicit way and this is a tiny little portion of what is out there available because after all we're not looking to get information.
Where are our main objective is to allow people to access knowledge and we can certainly not describe knowledge very very well, and so there's an implicit set way in which we do it.
And this is the sea beyond the visible part of the iceberg.
Now it turns out that 85% of Internet users when they go somewhere they know exactly where to go, and they most of the time know what they're trying to look for, but.
For the users like me and I'll give you a few examples.
This is not Sir.
Not the case, perhaps?
I mean the first question I asked is what is the course project and I have two examples here, one from a so-called engine called hockey and the other Google and.
Google managed to get it in position #4.
And the other one Hokio claims to be a natural language driven engine, doesn't have it.
It comes up with all kinds of other stuff.
Interesting, but not on the first page.
Then the interesting question is, which is the best project in the Sixth Framework Programme, whatever this means?
And again, hockey.
I mean really a minutes.
It goes all over the place but has no relevance whatsoever to the question that way.
Lost.
Google doesn't do a better job, and those are the kinds of questions that eventually, when they wish to ask.
Now, if you ask what is the best multimedia search engine in the world?
Excellent.
Gives some answers, but funny enough excellent themselves are not in the top ten.
Which one would expect it?
Achaea OK.
It's gets a bit closer, but I mean in terms of description, word, description but not, not really.
And then of course Google.

So I mean all of this to say that when you ask this sort of question and this is just the beginning of questions that could be asked, and as we move into the Internet of Tomorrow where things are going to become much more virtual, much more.
3D type the questions become more endlessly complex and the way in which we have to describe the content.
It becomes really key.
Let me get close.
Now.
This is where perhaps searches on the left you have a switchboard.
Nineteen 1050 years after we had a switchboard 1950.
So in 50 years this is where we have gone to from an operational 2 ladies.
The operation of perhaps 30 or 40 ladies, and this is roughly where search is today.
Now it should be noted that just ten years after 1960, or roughly.
Internet was born so the even the notion of switchboard disappeared because we now no longer have switches.
We have routers.
So in in long period of time, covering perhaps eight years, situation is rather stable and all of a sudden the meaning of a switchboard.
It disappeared, and perhaps this is something which we have to be confronted with.
Why?
Because the digital production is increasing enormously.
It's estimated that today worldwide with producing something like 160 exabytes of data.
Expected to be multiplied by 6 in a few days time and this contains not only.
Material produced by professionals as well as users, and this is Frances.
Things like pictures in Flickr or YouTube's and so on.
Now for those of you that don't know what exactly it is, it's a huge number.
And some people claim that this is 5 exabytes of data, is what?
It's if you wish the amount of data corresponding to all recorded output of every possible word ever uttered since the beginning of mankind.
So it's huge.
Now what is also expected that within three years or so, 70% of all the content will be produced and created.
Is 2 is going to come from from users.
In Europe, and you ask, this is important to note.
75% is where 75% of the content is today originated which which calls for of course.
Very critical questions to be asked because while the rest of the world, how about Asia Pacific?
How about Africa?
How about Latin America?

It's important to note that this is going to become an issue now in terms of this so called network amplifying phenomenon, and you can again say that some years ago 1998 there were 253 million email boxes and today the number has been multiplied by about 8.
So we're going to go to an unprecedented level of connectivity, thanks particularly to wireless communications.
We're going to go to situations where you're going to have a TB of storage in your pocket for perhaps 100 euros.

In five six years time, and we're going to be confronted with all kinds of situations where your devices through which you access information are going to be highly mobile and then location becomes extremely important.
Now search engine rankings.
Where are we today?
Worldwide?
If you look at latest statistics and I have another one which I'll show in a second on the left, you have comScore which shows that Google has about 56% of the market.
And this is the US market when it comes to the world.
It's even worse in some regions.
And I'll show you that in a second, then you have on the on the right hand side of the screen another another projection, another stat from heatwise which basically says the same thing.
Then the latest one I've seen is from Nielsen net ratings, which claims that again Google search has 53 roughly 50% of all the searches, and that corresponds to about 4.2 billion searches.
In one month.
OK, so this is colossal.
I mean so if you look at the others, the share of all the other search engines is.
Rather miniscule.
Now when you look at worlds and look at the different search rankings in selected regions, you look at France.
Google's Google has 80% of the market.
If you look at Russia, this is not the case.

If you look at China, China has they have their own search engine that has a huge market share and Google comes second and apparently from later starts I have seen from a report from from China dated 25th September the so called Baidu engine is now taking market share and Google is losing in the UK again.
I mean Google is ahead so worldwide.
The presence of Google is quite quite clearly, viz.
Now social networking.
Why do I talk about social networking?
But this is perhaps one of the most interesting dimensions.
When we think about search for the future and again some starts what is happening in various social networking sites.
Myspace, Facebook and the rest and you see here, here.
The growth in about 20 years since June 2006 to June 2007.
Unique number of visitors in millions or 114 million users for Myspace.
And you look at the percentage of change.
This is absolutely closer, so we're talking of growth growth rates, which are absolute.
Enormous.
So this is a phenomenon we have to cope with.
This is a map of social networking different.
Networks in the world will see that you see the blue areas in US and Canada.
So preference there goes to things like Facebook and Friendster.
Latin American is or quit or Brazil is or quit, and so it varies a bit from.
Answer to country.
Now why do I say poor social social social networking is important is that there has been an explosive growth and now you just saw the percentage of growth from June 2006, 2007.
This is estimated to go even faster in the future.
Now what does it mean concretely?
It means that there is roughly a billion users out there using these things.
Every day, 154 million people use this.
These networking sites.
3 billion minutes spent on it every day.
8 billion pages accessed every day, and those are some of the engines that you have and I now understand.
But bugs is associated with excellent right?
Which is an interesting phenomenon because it shows that search engines are gradually moving on to tackle other.
Other opportunities, and this is what this picture tries to reflect.
If you look at the various domains of activity like email, instant messaging, social network search engines, you see a combination of activities.
I haven't put excellent and bugs there, but it's it shows very well that you have, for instance, the Google Constellation, the Yahoo constellation, the Hotmail constellation, or MSN Constellation.
So I mean it's obvious that those who are interested in search are also interested in.
A variety of other services, and perhaps the best known exam.
Please search in Google.
Now, virtual worlds is perhaps the next step towards we should.
We should look into on the left I've put a picture of Second Life.
What is interesting about the picture is that this is a strike that has happened in IBM in Italy and there was a strike which was only visible in Second Life.
So the employees of IBM in Second Life went on strike.
They were demonstrating in Second life.
So it's interesting that this sort of thing happens.
Then in the middle you have this call, this thing called hippie high or.
I don't know how to pronounce it, which is the latest virtual world being put forward in China and you have of course a variety of other things like red alert and.
And games of all kinds, which which perhaps give a hint as to what may make heaters in terms of search, because if, how do we go about searching in a virtual world or sort of query makes sense?
How would we even describe the information in a virtual world?
How do we archive, categorize and search this data that is going to most likely come out of this now.
Virtual words are not do not necessarily mean that people go in there just for fun.
Companies such as Google again name it.

Again they have asking are they going to launch something called My world, which is a world where business can be conducted so it's not something just for fun for kids to play with like Second Life or more serious things.
But it is really a business oriented approach to describing virtual worlds and to allow businesses to tap onto this.
Potential.
Interesting also for you to know that when you look at users of secondlife the majority of them come from Europe.
Not from you, as you would have expected that to be the case, but no.
Europe has 61% of users.
At least this is the last account around, I think.
March March this year.
North America has 19% of users.
Asia Pacific 13%.
So for some reason it is primarily in Germany that people are addicted to second life for reasons which we have to do.
Culture I guess.
Now here here I would like to having spoken about social networks and virtual worlds.
Perhaps one should look at pictures such as this which remains is important because it's for us.
What we have to think of is how are going to evolve and whether not we're going to evolve to something which could be a 3D Internet.

If this is a situation, if we're going to progressively move from where, basically right today, that is a static web for something which is my space OK, and then Google Earth and then Second Life and then virtual worlds, sooner or later we'll end up with something which you could describe as a 3D Internet, and then if this is the case, what are the basic features that features that characterize these 3D Internet and how again do we go about finding information, extracting information?
And above all, extracting knowledge?
And this is an area where we would like to do more in the coming work program of the ICT theme in the framework program seven.
We have not yet explored this enough and this is perhaps an area that.
Is a quite quite promising area.
OK, so you said that now our contributions so far to this has been a series of projects.
Chorus is the flagship that drives and coordinates and allows you to coordinate amongst yourself is a very important project.
Then we have two VIPs.
Vigilius and photos and then we have a number of straps and this is the constellation we now have in place.
Each one of them has its own specific features.
I'm not going to say more about that because you certainly know no more.
More than I know about it, but perhaps we can speak for a second as to what the progress and results have been so far.
So if you look at things like victory in Vitalus.
They actually working towards discovering advanced solutions for organizing searching audiovisual content in 3D objectives.
Again, again, not again.
This is an indication that 3D is becoming really important.
Then course OK. You know what the mandate is.
Thinktank Usecases benchmarking, Roadmapping and so on.
So peer peer to peer search engine.
For us adaptive search by content tripod with elements of Geo location and again 3D City models, which again indicates a 3D is is more than just a buzzword.
And then last last bit covered by project such as diversity, media rushes and video video.
There is an element of 3D graphical objects in there.
This is a very in a very compressed way.
I mean what we think.
This has been.
But today as we see it, search engine are in the in the context of you is.
The emphasis is basically on these various bullets.
Is looking into future user service requirements.
Can take into account specifically the fact that access is going to become more and more obtained via devices which are portable or mobile.
The context of search geographical location is becoming more important.
Multiple environments, local enterprise and open Internet is important as well, and so on.
I'm not going to read read it all.
What we believe in is that this all represents a unique opportunity for you people to come together and share experiences, share results.
And hopefully at the end of the day.
Do something which is good for Europe now.
Our ambition from the Commission is to help you sail into the future.
And why do I say sale?
Because I mean we happened to be in Switzerland and Switzerland got.
Right, so there's this boat which is not a Swiss boat but doesn't matter, but at least they won the America's Cup.
So it's setting in the future means that I mean, Corps in particular would would should be in a position to develop and create a solid basis for coordination, and this is absolutely essential.
We should allow, and this is sometimes not easy.
People to develop disruptive ideas.
Non Orthodox thinking.
Without which, if we simply look at the business requirements from companies that have, sometimes a six month horizon, we're not going to get anywhere.
We have to allow for this disruption.

Coming above all would like for you to avail yourselves of the technological and economic opportunities that this may mean an eventually if we can help you conquer more than just European market, that would be great.
Thank you very much for your attention.
